s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentGAVIN  Stacey was based in Barry after Little Britain star Matt Lucas provided the foot in the door for people unfamiliar with James Corden.That was the situation, location manager Clive Evans, has revealed while he was scouting for places in which the award-winning could be based.And Weston-super-Mare could have masqueraded as lsquoWalesrsquoBarry hadnrsquot won the production companyrsquos heart.Freelance Location manager, Clive Evans, whose projects also include The Bill The Story of Tracey Beaker Doctor Who Very Annie Mary, Young Dracula You Get Me and As If, used Mr Lucas as an ice-breaker as James Corden, in , was relatively unknown and Mr Lucas was featuring in the new series.MORE STORIESGavin and Stacey fans flock to Barry Island to catch sight of the locationsSupporters who helped make Gavin  Stacey happen in BarryThe Gavin and Stacey effect -  years onMr Evans, of Cardigan in West Wales, but now living in Brecon, said: ldquoIrsquod taken a call back in  to check my availability for a small comedy for BBC Three and set in South Wales.ldquoI met up with Christine Gernonand Ruth Jonesat the Castell Mynach pub near Llantrisant one afternoon to discuss the script and the locations they wanted me to scout.ldquoAn hour or so after the meeting, I got the call from the production company Baby Cow offering me the job.ldquoMy first task was to sit with Dave Ferrisand discuss the vision for Gavin  Staceyrsquos backdrop and get a feel for the key locations.ldquoStaceyrsquos hometown was scripted as a South Wales coastal town, but I was given a free run on this so the hunt took me to Aberavon, Porthcawl, Tenby, Saundersfoot, and Weston-super-Mare - a cheatit had been suitable.ldquoBack in  there were a few areas in Barry which were beginning to look a little tired, but it also came with a timeless charm that provided us with the perfect texture and feel that Dave and I had discussed.ldquoAdded to this was the welcome we were given by residents and, in particular, the support of the local council.ldquoPorthcawl was also a serious candidate for the backdrop to this show, but having scouted tirelessly the whole of Barry and Barry Island, I knew that this ticked every box.Mr Evans said Trinity Street was an instant favourite.ldquoI knew Gwenrsquos house was here, he said. ldquoThe terraced houses on a steep hill and its far-reaching views over to Barry Island and docks meant that no matter which direction the camera was pointing, there would be interesting textures and views.ldquoThe next objective was to get inside as many houses as possible to seeany worked for us as Gwenrsquos house.ldquoI letter dropped about  houses to gauge the interest.ldquoIrsquod heard that Matt Lucas was going to be involved so I used his name get to my foot in the door.ldquoThis usually helps.ldquoIn those days very few had heard of James Corden.ldquoI viewed and took pictures of about five houses on that street and Glendarsquos who was one of the first to contact me.ldquoThe decor and character of Glendarsquos house fitted my brief perfectly, but my first thought was that house was a little on the small side.ldquoTo get a film crew and the actors to work in such a tight space would be quite a challenge, butI could convince our director and designer that it could be achieved Gwenrsquos house was found.ldquoI took Dave and Christine along to Trinity Street and both fell in love with the location within minutes.Mr Evans continued: ldquoGlenda was so accommodating.ldquoI remember very well discussing with her the details of how filming on location works, how disruptive the whole process can be and also the location fee.ldquoWhat I do remember was her reaction when I mentioned the amount.ldquoGlendarsquos reply was: ldquoIrsquom so sorry Clive, but I donrsquot think I can cover that.ldquoGlenda thought that she needed to pay for the privilege of having us there and not the other way round.ldquoShe is a lovely lady and still loves being a part of the Gavin  Stacey world.During the locationsrsquo breakdown meeting, we discussed how Pam and Mickrsquos house might look in Billericay so homes were viewed in and around Llandaff and Sully until Dinas Powys was selected thanks to the welcome that was received.ldquoSt Cattwgrsquos Church at Llanmaes was not the first-choice wedding venue for Gavin and Stacey, Mr Evans said. ldquoThey were due to be married at St Nicholas Church at the village of St Nicholas, but a last-minute change of heart by the Church in Wales meant that we needed to find an alternative at the th hour.ldquoA friend and another locations manager called Chris Hill pulled in a favour and we were able to use St Cattwgrsquos.ldquoI dont recall any candidates other than Island Leisure .ldquoWhile filming on the front, Marco opening up early for the crew to be able to get a nice coffee as the weather was pretty unkind.ldquoWe didnt use the interior of the coffee shop as a location in series one, but as it was so cold when we filmed on the seafront the coffees were very welcome.ldquoWe also filmed at the Vale of Glamorgan Resort for the exterior of the wedding fair.ldquoThe interior was shot at the Copthorne Hotel at Culverhouse Cross.ldquoWhile at the Vale resort, the Wales rugby team came into the reception of the hotel.ldquoRuth Jones askedIrsquod be able to set up a photograph of the cast with the Welsh team.ldquoWe got them to agree so out there somewhere are pictures of the Gavin  Stacey cast with the Wales rugby team.ldquoUncle Brynrsquos house was only an exterior in series one so very little was involved in its search.ldquoQuiz night at the Colcot Arms was interesting.ldquoWe were close to completing our filming when the pub opened to the public - so the last few shots took a little while longer than wersquod planned.Mr Evans lives with his we Rhiannon and daughter Cerys Mim and runs his own Film and TV Facilities company.He added: ldquoThe actors usually donrsquot get to see the locations beforehand.ldquoThey are brought to set, run through a quick rehearsal then go for the real thing.ldquoThey then have to go through the whole thing over and over with the camera shooting from dferent angles.ldquoIt is a slow process and  hours on camera gives us around three minutes of footage.ldquoI get a real buzz from seeing locations that I have found on TV, but when it comes to Gavin  Stacey the story I always bring up is that while scouting in the very early days with the series producer in the car he askedI would consider reading for Dave.ldquoMy le could have been so dferent, but I have no regrets as no-one could have played it better than Steffan Rhodri.ldquoMy daughter Cerys Mim was born during filming and James Corden was the first to congratulate me when I ed to work on the show after her birth.ldquoHe joked about us naming her Nessa or Stacey.ldquoBarry and the Vale have always provided me with a fantastic hunting ground for film and TV locations.ldquoIts a huge contributor to South Wales becoming a hotspot for filming in the last decade or so. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey The new site will officially be named Harland  Wolffand we are pleased to be building on our globally recognised brand. #INFA pic RuXDLFkeImdash InfraStrata plcAugust , Discussions are already under way with the Government and private vessel owners, InfraStrata said.The site was previously operated by Babcock but closed in March .Its new owners hope the Ministry of Defence, Home Office and Department for Transport will choose a British yard for work on planned vessels.The yard also hopes to secure work on wind farm projects.InfraStratarsquos chief executive John Wood said: ldquoThe acquisition at this point in time is opportunistic for the company and one that should not be missed.ldquoIt not only gives us a strategic foothold in mainland UK but also makes the overall business highly competitive in the smaller and higher ends of the shipyard market, respectively.Absolutely brilliant news this morning for #NorthDevonndash deal done on Appledore Shipyard. and we welcome its purchase by InfraStrata.ldquoAppledore played a vital role making the complex bows for the aircraft carrier and it could play a similar role building the future solid support ship which the Government must build in Britain in order to invest in our regional economies and get the economy back up and running.GMB union organiser Matt Roberts said: ldquoWe are absolutely delighted network of box-like charging stations, where users can swap out batteries to earn free rides.It comes as new regulations enabling trials of rental e-scooters came into force at the beginning of July, to assess whether e-scooters reduce motor traffic and what impact they have on the safety of users and those around them.The fully automated charging stations can be placed inside existing businesses to boost customer visits, such as in convenience stores or cafes, with all required electricity provided by the host covered by Tier, the company said. vw,vw,px, px"Launch of the new Tier e-scooter took place in central London on Tuesday London-based startup Pushme ndash acquired by Tier earlier this year ndash developed the technology and has a manufacturing base in Aylesbury, Oxfordshire.The new scooters will debut in Tampere, Finland, where a fleet of , devices will be supported by a network of  charging stations across the city.By the end of , the company plans to roll out its swappable battery technology across all its operations, which currently sit at more than  cities across nine countries.Tierrsquos latest e-scooters feature a foldable helmet, as well as indicator lights on the steering bar and back fender to signal the riderrsquos direction to other road users.ldquoToday marks a step change in safe and sustainable travel around our cities, said Lawrence Leuschner, chief executive and co-founder of Tier.ldquoBy integrating this new kind of swappable battery technology, we are building a Europe-wide charging network that allows users to play an active part in adopting climate-neutral travel and building better cities.ldquoAt the same time, by hosting the charging pods in local businesses, we are helping high streets to recover from lockdown.ldquoThis is a crucial step in Tierrsquos electric revolution to make mobility better.ldquoIt is our plan that in time our charging network will not just service e-scooters, but other vehicles too.As part of a -month trial of e-scooters across the UK, only rentals are allowed on roads, limited to .mph.Riders who participate in the pilots will need a full or provisional car, motorcycle or moped licence, must be aged at least  and will be urged to wear a helmet.Emma Drackford, communications director at Electrical Safety First, said: ldquoAs our lives become increasingly electric, it is important consumers only purchase items such as e-bikes and e-scooters from reputable retailers.ldquoWhilst cities around the country trial public hire schemes, privately owned models, which are not yet legal for use on public land, will need to be charged at home and consumers should be wary of purchasing low quality, substandard imitations which could pose a signicant fire risk..push,i[r].l*new story: Car destroyed in arson attackMissing person - Gordie WalkerNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsCall for temporary driving test centre for CraigavonLearner drivers from Craigavon can no longer take driving tests locally as the DVA at Carn is being used as a COVID- test centre.By Carmel RobinsonTuesday, th August , : am""As the first driving tests since Lockdown begin on September , concerns have been raised that those from Craigavon will be unable to avail of this facility.A number of local politicians have voiced concern that those from Craigavon may be disadvantaged and Sinn Fein has called fora a temporary driving test facility to be set up.Upper Bann MP Carla Lockhart and DUP Cllrs Margaret Tinsley and Tim McClelland urged Infrastructure Minister Nichola Mallon MLA to reintroduce driver testing at Craigavon immediately, after local motorists were informed that tests would have to be undertaken at other centres – including Lisburn and Armagh.Mrs Lockhart said: “This situation is untenable and places local motorists at a distinct disadvantage be it for driving, trailer and HGV tests.“This week I have received representation from each of the sectors that use Craigavon and they are very distressed about the impact it will have on their respective businesses.Some of these sectors are the main supply for our haulage and agricultural industry. “Craigavon Test Centre covers a very wide geographical area and is one of the busiest centres in Northern Ireland with a large number of tests being conducted every year,” said Mrs Lockhart who said she took comfort in taking her test on roads she knew. “That is a comfort that will not be available to local learner drivers who are taking their driving test. That is unfair. “I have raised this with the Minister and asked her to urgently review this decision and to quickly reinstate these test.I have requested a meeting with her so that the instructors can highlight their concerns.”Sinn Féin MLA John O’Dowd called for the opening of temporary driving test facility in Craigavon while the normal center is used for Covid  testing.Mr O’Dowd said: “While I welcome the commencement of Driving Tests across the North I have to express my disappoint they will not be recommencing in Craigavon. I understand the use of the current center for Covid  testing rules out this facility however other facilities could be used to keep tests in the Craigavon area.“I have written to Minister Mallon and asked for other options to be explored and another venue identied to allow learner drivers to complete their tests.”A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. story: Car destroyed in arson attackMissing person - Gordie WalkerNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPoliticsVJ Day event welcomed by DUP and SFArmagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council’s event to celebrate the th anniversary of VJ Day has been welcomed by both the DUP and Sinn Fein.By The NewsroomThursday, th August , : pm""Council has confirmed a shared history event to mark the occasion will take place this Saturday, August .Many local people were heldas Japanese prisoners of war and the stories of their experience still haunt the families to this day.The event will include a lecture from renowned historian Dr Eamon Phoenix, poetry reading by local historian Richard Edgar and a musical accompaniment from piper Ian Burrows.Speaking about the event, Council’s Lord Mayor, Councillor Kevin Savage said: “Shared history events are important for a ided society.“We hope that by embracing social media and digital technology we can attract wider audiences comprised of people who – for ious reasons – might not normally attend such an event in person.“With COVID- still very much a concern at the moment, we are hoping to run more online events like these to ensure we’re minimising the risk to our residents while still offering the excellent events we’re known for, albeit in a slightly dferent way.”DUP group whip Councillor Darryn Causby said it was important for Council to mark the occasion, widely regarded as the end of the second World War.“It is important for Council to mark this occasion,” he said.“We are obviously disappointed that it could not be marked in a more substantial way than what we are doing.“However, we welcome the fact all parties recognise the vital role the British Army played during the second World War and we welcome that across the piece.”Speaking about ABC Council’s shared history event SinnFein group leader, Councillor Liam Mackle said: “Many local people lost their lives in this conflict.“The Lord Mayor will pay special tribute to local man Jim Haughey. Jim fought against fascismin the International Brigade in the Spanish Civil War and was later killed in .“Council officers deserve special praise for organising this event which was inclusive and contributed to our shared understanding of history.”Initially proposed by DUP group leader, Councillor Mark Baxter duringthe course of July’s full council meeting, the idea to hold a socially distanced event compliant with COVID regulations was put to a vote following a fiery debate.In total,  members voted for the proposal with the DUP, UUP, Alliance Party and IndependentCouncillorPaul Berry in support of the proposal.The five SDLP members present abstained and the nine Sinn Fein members present voted against the proposal.The event will be broadcast on Council’s facebook page from -.am on Saturday, August .
